bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 1. So much of my time was engaged in reading this forenoon that I wrote scarcely half a page of my first Sketches— Dined with the Corporation at the Steward’s— At 2. O’Clock I read my fourth lecture— It was received with more than ordinary attention— Accomplished my afternoon’s writing; and in the Evening walk’d to the Bridge— Mr: Shaw was here at my lecture and told me that my brother’s wife had a daughter—

2. Engaged all the forenoon in writing, but not upon my proper business. Dr: and Mrs: Waterhouse this afternoon went to Andover— I went in the Stage to Boston, having some expectation of Mrs: Adams’s arrival there; and intending to go out in the Quincy Stage. I was however too late for the Stage, and Mrs: Adams did not arrive. I therefore walk’d out to Quincy, though under a continual drizzling mist— I was 2 hours and 3 minutes walking from South-Boston Bridge—South side, to my father’s door Whence I conclude the distance to be 7 miles and 1/6th.

3. Heard Mr: Whitney, an occasional Sermon, on the death of poor Mitchell, and Peter Hardwick, his boy who were drown’d last Tuesday Afternoon. An Event which, has caused universal affliction in this place.— In the afternoon I went to my own house where I found most of the furniture arranged, and the house ready for our reception— Evening at my fathers— I read but little, and wrote nothing this day. My brothers Daughter was born Tuesday Evening the 29th: one minute before midnight.

4. Came into Boston this morning with my brother, and procured a number of Articles to be sent out to Quincy, on Wednesday.— At 12. I took the Stage and came up to Cambridge— In the afternoon early Mr: Hedge the Tutor called upon me to enquire, whether I had been in Boston, at the time of the Tragical incident which occurr’d— It happened about an hour after I came out of town— T. O. Selfridge in the newspaper this morning advertised B. Austin as a liar and a coward, for having slandered him in respect to his professional character, and refused him satisfaction— Austin
in the other paper advertised that he should take no other notice of Selfridge’s publication than to say that if any gentleman wished to know the Evidence upon which he had spoken of Selfridge, he should be furnished with it on application to him— But Austin’s son, a young Man, who was to have graduated at the ensuing Commencement, attacked Selfridge with a cane in the Street; upon which Selfridge drew a pistol from his pocket, and shot him dead. Selfridge was committed to prison; and the verdict of the Coroner’s Inquest upon the body was wilful murder.— Dr: and Mrs: Waterhouse returned from Andover this afternoon— I accomplished my usual afternoon’s writing— Walk’d in the Evening, and call’d at Judge Dana’s.

5. Spent the day, assiduously employed upon my business— My Morning progress however was small and that of the afternoon more laborious than usual— Finished the fair copy of my seventh Lecture, and began the Eighth— Walk’d in the Evening.

6. Examination of the Junior Class by a Committee of the Overseers and Corporation— Mr: Holmes was Chairman— I dined with them at Mr: Gannett’s— In the afternoon I attended the examination—by Mr: Hedge in Locke—Mr: Nicholls in Mathematics, and Mr Ware in Theology— The examination finished soon after three O’Clock— The College Government being all engaged to attend the funeral of young Austin— I employed the whole day to its ordinary purpose & without waste.

7. Attended a declamation this afternoon— The last division of the Sophomore Class— They continue to have their pieces well, by heart. But the speakers of this day were all indifferent— Mr: and Mrs: Gray of Roxbury were here in the afternoon.— Walked to the Brookline Corner this Evening—

div.p: 8. Wrote assiduously part of the forenoon— And employed the remainder in packing up to leave Cambridge— Mr: Randall dined with us— At 2. I delivered my fifth Lecture— Mr: Shaw, with several other Gentlemen from Boston attended, and gave me a seat in their Carriage— I came into Boston to meet Mrs: Adams, whom I now expect hourly to arrive— And finally left Dr: Waterhouse’s, where I have spent seven weeks as pleasantly as was possible separated from my family and employed in a manner entirely satisfactory to myself— Suited equally to my inclinations and my duties— The Dr: has a very amiable family— Mrs: Waterhouse is a woman uniting pleasantness of disposition with activity and Spirit— Her mother Mrs: Oliver, with a less cultivated Education, has much good sense, and experience in the management of a family— The two eldest Sons, Andrew and John, are at the Academy at Andover— There are at home two sons, Daniel and Benjamin, and two Daughters Elizabeth and Mary. The eldest about 14. the youngest 7— All good tempered, and well-behaved children. When I got into Boston, I took a chamber at Whitcomb’s, and wrote my usual afternoon’s task— Called on Mr: J. Gardner, and walk’d with him and Mr: Jos: Hall in the Mall, untill 9. in the Evening.

9. Dr: Waterhouse sent in Daniel with a letter for me, taken from the Post-Office at Cambridge this Morning. It was from Philadelphia, dated 30. July— Shortly after William brought me another, which came from Quincy. This was dated New-York the 3d: of this Month— She intended to stay there, over Commencement which was on the 6th:— I concluded upon this not to go out to Quincy this afternoon, but to expect her here— Dined with Mr: W. Smith— Mr: Shaw, and a young Mr: Montgomery from Alicant were there— Afternoon wrote as usual— Walk in the Evening with Mr: Gardner.

10. Mr: Gardner called upon me this morning, and I went with him to the Brattle-Street Meeting-House, where we had a Sermon from Mr: Kendall of Weston— I dined with Mr: Gardner, and in the afternoon I went to Trinity-Church— Both the Sermons, were allusive to the late tragical Event in this Town— After Church I returned to my chamber, and at about 6 in the Evening Mrs: Adams and Caroline Johnson arrived— Having left New-York between two and three O’Clock the day before yesterday in the afternoon— They came from Providence this morning.

11. At 11. O’Clock this morning we left Boston, and came out to my father’s at Quincy where we dined— My father was at Weymouth— Immediately after dinner we came to our own house— After which I went once more down to my father’s to bring home part of the Articles we had left there— We were employed the whole afternoon and Evening in putting the house into order, as much as possible— We have a boy—Charles Adams, brother of Newell who lived with us last Summer; but have yet been able to procure no woman— We brought our children home; but John was so desirous to go back with his Grandmother, that we had great difficulty to keep him.

12. Had rather an uneasy and restless Night; consequently was not very well this day, and found myself quite incapable of the application necessary for my morning Studies— Consequently the forenoon was principally lost— In the afternoon however with some difficulty I accomplished my ordinary task— Finished the fair copy of the 8th: and began the ninth lecture— In the Evening I walk’d to my father’s and spent an hour there— We yet suffer the inconveniences of beginning to keep house, and have no servant except the boy.

13. I went to my father’s early this morning, and accompanied him to Cambridge— There we attended a meeting of the Academy— The meeting was thin, and President Webber was not there— The business transacted was inconsiderable; but an Essay of N. Webster on the Story of Phaeton was read— We dined at Judge Dana’s, and immediately after dinner returned to Quincy— Found Mrs: Adams, Caroline, and John at my father’s— We came home early in the Evening— The day has been lost to my occupations.

div.p: 14. Finished reading through the Greek Testament this morning— Then went to Cambridge with Mrs: Adams; and we took John with us— We stop’d at Dr: Waterhouse’s, where we arrived between 10 and 11. From that time untill 5. in the afternoon, I was engaged, in examining compositions for Commencement, and for the Exhibition next week—excepting at dinner Time; and at the Declamation which I attended at 2 O’Clock— The Sophomores finished, and the Juniors began— But the performance on the whole was indifferent.— We returned to Quincy this Evening; coming through Boston— Reached home about 8.— The day though wholly devoted to the performance of my duty, has been totally lost to my own improvement.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 15. Went to Cambridge this morning again— Heard the performers for the next exhibition—from 11. in the forenoon, untill 4. this afternoon; with the interval of an hour at dinner, and an hour for my 6th: Lecture— In the Evening I returned to Quincy— Stop’d at my father’s both going and returning.— Began reading the Greek Testament again.

16. Employed the day, as attentively as I could in the composition of my Lectures— But numerous cares now necessarily distract my attention— In the Evening I went to my father’s— My Mother is very unwell— And William the black man in coming from Boston fell from the Cart, which pass’d over him.—

17. Heard Mr: Foster of little Cambridge,—the whole day. His Morning Subject wasand that of the afternoon the duty, and benefits of prayer— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was here afterwards; and my brother in the Evening— The drowth as usual at this Season of the year is excessive, but this afternoon we had a very copious Shower; after which the Evening was clear—

18. Day employed generally as it ought to be; though I do not yet apply with sufficient assiduity to my forenoon’s task— That of the afternoon is much less laborious, but advances me nothing in my work— Mrs: Adams and Caroline rode out this afternoon with John— I walk’d down to my father’s, at the beginning of the Evening— After I returned as I was reading Cumberland’s Memoirs to the Ladies, we were alarmed by John’s falling out of bed in the chamber over our heads— He received a severe bruise in the head, and bit his lip badly in the fall, but we hope without dangerous injury.

19. Mrs: and Miss Apthorp, Miss Morton and Miss Jackson were here this forenoon— My father also called for a half an hour— Mrs: Cranch, with A. Shaw were here this afternoon at tea— My morning task still underwent some entrenchment this day— That of the afternoon I accomplished as usual— The day before yesterday, I began anew the lessons of french reading with George— He had entirely forgotten all that I took so much pains to teach him last Summer— But as he now can read, he will learn faster than he did before— I give him two lessons a day—

20. Mr: and Mrs: T. Greenleaf and their Son were here this Evening— I went to my father’s, where I met Mr: & Mrs: Black— Employed the day properly— Finished the fair copy of my Ninth Lecture— On the Topics— I am more dissatisfied with it, than with any that I have yet written—

21. Went into Boston this Morning in the Quincy Stage; and at 12. in the Stage from Boston to Cambridge— Return’d in the afternoon to Boston and to Quincy, by the same conveyance— Walk’d in the Evening with the Ladies— Young T. Greenleaf spent the Evening with us— In Boston I executed my Will; cancelling that which I made 10. July 1802— Heard the declamation at Cambridge— A Mr: Chandler of Andover dined with us at Dr: Waterhouse’s.

22. Mrs: Miller—Mrs: D. Greenleaf, and Mr: Quincy were here this forenoon— In the afternoon we went to my father’s where there was a large party of Ladies— But we were engaged at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s— We returned home early this Evening— While I was at my father’s we had a short thunder gust, with wind, rain, and hail, as sudden and violent, as I ever witness’d— To my studies this day was almost totally lost.

div.p: 23. Rained steadily, almost through the whole day; we were of course all confined to the house— I went through my ordinary task for both parts of the day— Began the fair copy of my tenth lecture— I am much dissatisfied with this part of my work, and can only depend upon the advantage of going thoroughly over the subject again on the revisal; if it please Heaven, that I should get completely through the course— My own present ideas are so crude and indigested, that my only hope is, at some future day, to look back upon them, as upon the essays of a noviciate— As a foundation to improve upon they may answer. But in no other respect are they supportable to my own reflections.

24. Incessant rain again the whole day through, which kept us entirely confined to the house, though Sunday— It was attended with a strong gale, which towards Evening became a very violent Tempest— I did not entirely spend the day in idleness; but wrote much less than I should have done.

25. The weather cleared up in the Night, and this day has been fair— I employed in my proper business— Went to my father’s this afternoon, and he was at my house in the morning— Spent the Evening at Mr: Apthorp’s.— I retrieved this afternoon the part of my business which I yesterday fell short.

26. I continue writing both parts of the day— But the morning task very heavily labours, and I grow daily more dissatisfied with my work— I did not however this day neglect it— I also attempted to bud some peach-trees— But my lectures take up so much of my time, that I have scarcely time to teach George his lesson of French, or to take my own of Greek.

div.p: 27. Soon after six this morning I went with Mrs: Adams to Cambridge, through Boston; we got to Dr: Waterhouse’s soon after 9 O’Clock, and found Caroline had that moment arrived with my brother— They left Quincy about half an hour after us. We shortly after conducted the Ladies to their Seats, after which I went to the Library and Philosophy Chamber— Thence, some time after ten we moved in Procession— The performances began shortly before eleven, and closed about 3. P.M.— We dined with Mr: T. K. Jones who had a son that graduated, and spoke one of the Orations— The dinner was at Read’s— And about 300 persons there— In the Evening we called at Mr: Ware’s, and at Dr: Hill’s, where I found Mrs: Brown, whom I formerly knew as Miss C. Jones of Newbury Port— She came over to Dr: Waterhouse’s, where, we had an agreeable Evening— Caroline went into Boston with young Mrs: Danforth— The same observations which I made upon the Commencement last year, are applicable to the performances of this day— Excepting that they were this day not so good, and all their defects more conspicuous— The failures of Memory were much more gross; and Mr: Savage the English Orator, of the Masters degree appeared scarcely to have read his own Oration a second time— This total and almost universal neglect of Memory has crept on to such a degree, altogether from the indulgence in the College, which I am endeavouring to reform—

bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 28. Called on the President this Morning to request his attention to the arrangement I have proposed for delivering my lecture and hearing the declamation in future on the same day weekly; which he promised to do during the vacation— While I was there Mr: Harris and Mr: Pierce came from the Ф.B.K. Society, to request the use of the Chapel for their meeting—which he granted— I went with Mrs: Adams to the library—Philosophy Chamber and Museum— Between 11. and 12. We went to the Meeting House, where a Poem was Spoken by Mr: B. Whitwell, and an Oration by my brother; for the Ф.B.K. fraternity.— The poem was an Allegorical Tale, very well written and well delivered—the Oration was good, but spoken so low that great part of it could not be heard— After the performances were finished I attended the meeting of the Society, for a few minutes, but was obliged to leave them to go to dinner, at Dr: Waterhouse’s— In the afternoon, we called for a few minutes at Mr: Greenleaf’s, and returned to Quincy where we arrived at about 8 in the Evening.— My brother and Caroline got home about half an hour after us—

29. Sally Cleverly the maid who lives with us was this day seized with the inflammatory sore throat, or scarlet fever— I took the two children immediately to Mr: Cranch’s— But John was reluctant at staying, and in the Evening went down to my father’s— I went with Mr: T. Greenleaf this afternoon to Dr: Warren’s, at Jamaica Plain, and we returned in the Evening.— Dr: Hayward, a Dr: Willard, & his son, and young Dr: Warren, and his wife were there— I brought some pear-buds, (brown bury) and peach buds (white magdalen, & chancellor) from Dr: Warren’s— Dr: Welsh was here this afternoon.

30. I have again entirely wasted this day, which I spent, the forenoon about the garden, budding & trimming fruit trees; the afternoon at my father’s, where there was a large party of Ladies and Gentlemen, at tea— Mr: I. Smith was there, and Mr: C. Bradbury, who came out from Boston with Mr: Shaw— My Father dined at Mr: Pomeroy’s—Cambridge. I called to see George, at Mr: Cranch’s.

31. Heard Mr: Isaac Smith the whole day— His Sermons are very good, but his manner of speaking is remarkably unpleasant— This afternoon my brother’s daughter was baptized by the name of Abigail Smith— Mr: Quincy also had a daughter baptized. I went to my father’s in the afternoon; and to Mr: Quincy’s in the Evening— With him I revised the Regulations of the Neponset Bridge Corporation— There was a thunder shower this Evening which made me late home.

Day. Rise at 6. Read 3 Chapters in the Greek Testament, and 5. Psalms in the English Bible— Loiter and lounge in the Garden untill 9. Breakfast— In the garden again, another hour— Write first sketch of my lecture, sometimes— Dine between one and 2. Garden again— Write the fair copy of my lecture untill 6. Walk an hour— Read—Cumberland’s Memoirs untill 9. Sup— Bed, between 10 and 11— This is no longer the studious life of the two former months— I have wasted the past week, and fear I shall waste the next— Nothing can be more fatal to study than petty avocations continually recurring— My lectures are already losing two thirds of their value.
